values.title: Make models semi-transparent while being manipulated

content.raw:
Users often get confused by how the rotation and translation tools work. Many assume the model is being moved in the physics at the same time as the mouse is dragging it, but in reality, the pose only changes for the physics side once the mouse is released.

One way to make it clear for users that this is happening would be by making the model semi-transparent similarly to how it is when we display an alignment "preview":

1. Mouse press on manipulation tool - model turns transparent

2. Mouse dragging tool - model moves while still transparent

3. Mouse release - model goes back to original color indicating that it's not a preview anymore.

Note that there have been discussions on making the manipulation tool actually drag models/links, which would make this issue invalid. See more on issue #998
content.html:
Users often get confused by how the rotation and translation tools work. Many assume the model is being moved in the physics at the same time as the mouse is dragging it, but in reality, the pose only changes for the physics side once the mouse is released.

One way to make it clear for users that this is happening would be by making the model semi-transparent similarly to how it is when we display an alignment "preview":

  1. Mouse press on manipulation tool - model turns transparent

  2. Mouse dragging tool - model moves while still transparent

  3. Mouse release - model goes back to original color indicating that it's not a preview anymore.

Note that there have been discussions on making the manipulation tool actually drag models/links, which would make this issue invalid. See more on issue #998

values.title: Live-update of fields in ModelListWidget

content.raw:
Currently the `ModelListWidget` displays information about selected models, links and joints. It has some useful numerical data, like entity pose and joint angle. It would be nice if these data values could be updated in real-time. @chapulina said that gzweb already does this.

In the meantime, by clicking on an entity a second time, the data values are updated, but the interface flickers, so that is hard to visually see the change (I believe it is re-creating the QT widgets instead of updating the existing fields). I've made a [short video](https://vimeo.com/147885602) to show this. It's actually even worse for the pose, which has to be re-expanded to see the numerical values every time you click again.

values.title: Migrate to qt5

content.raw:
From [announcement of qt 4.8.7](http://blog.qt.io/blog/2015/05/26/qt-4-8-7-released/):

"Qt 4.8.7 is planned to be the last patch release of the Qt 4 series. Standard support is available until December 2015, after which extended support will be available. We recommend all active projects to migrate to Qt 5, as new operating systems and compilers with Qt 4.8 will not be supported."

Standard support for qt4 ends this month.

values.title: `ContactManager::CreateFilter()` and `ContactManager::RemoveFilter()` are inconsistent

content.raw:
When creating a contact filter through `ContactManager::CreateFilter()`, it performs a string replace to change all "::" to "/". However, `ContactManager::RemoveFilter()` does not do the same thing. This means that whenever a filter is created where the name has "::" in it, a call to `RemoveFilter` with the same name does not remove it.

As it so happens the `ContactSensor` adds such a filter - when such a sensor is removed its contact filter lingers.
content.html:
When creating a contact filter through ContactManager::CreateFilter(), it performs a string replace to change all "::" to "/". However, ContactManager::RemoveFilter() does not do the same thing. This means that whenever a filter is created where the name has "::" in it, a call to RemoveFilter with the same name does not remove it.

As it so happens the ContactSensor adds such a filter - when such a sensor is removed its contact filter lingers.

values.title: Make it possible for a color to be invalid

content.raw:
In the  GUI library, we are using `QColor` quite often. It would be nice to start using more of `common::Color` instead. 

One of the features of `QColor` which we make use of and don't have in `common::Color` yet is the idea of an ["invalid"](http://doc.qt.io/qt-4.8/qcolor.html#QColor) color.

values.title: Scene camera name clashes when using multiple `CameraSensor`s

content.raw:
Say we have two identical models in the world, which are equipped with a camera sensor. Though the model names are different, the local camera sensor names will be identical (due to the models being the same internally). If we look at [CameraSensor.cc:117](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/49af615a6e6e65dc97ed81c4b9cfc96fb0d8cd61/gazebo/sensors/CameraSensor.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#CameraSensor.cc-117), scene cameras are created using the local sensor name, rather than the scoped name. This means that whenever one of the models is deleted, and `RemoveCamera` is called in [CameraSensor::173](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/49af615a6e6e65dc97ed81c4b9cfc96fb0d8cd61/gazebo/sensors/CameraSensor.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#CameraSensor.cc-173), it is going to delete the camera of the first sensor that was added, regardless of whether this is the camera corresponding to the sensor.

The camera should use the fully scoped name of the sensor instead to prevent this issue. See https://bitbucket.org/ElteHupkes/gazebo/commits/2a7c5d6cd9b3aef9015d67866030040503aa87d5 for suggested fix.
content.html:
Say we have two identical models in the world, which are equipped with a camera sensor. Though the model names are different, the local camera sensor names will be identical (due to the models being the same internally). If we look at CameraSensor.cc:117, scene cameras are created using the local sensor name, rather than the scoped name. This means that whenever one of the models is deleted, and RemoveCamera is called in CameraSensor::173, it is going to delete the camera of the first sensor that was added, regardless of whether this is the camera corresponding to the sensor.

The camera should use the fully scoped name of the sensor instead to prevent this issue. See https://bitbucket.org/ElteHupkes/gazebo/commits/2a7c5d6cd9b3aef9015d67866030040503aa87d5 for suggested fix.

values.title: Arrows of `AxisVisual` are never removed from scene

content.raw:
When a`Visual` is removed in `Scene::RemoveVisual()`, it calls `Scene::RemoveVisualizations()` in order to delete eventual additional GUI visualizations of the visual. It only removes these visuals if they are of the type `VT_PHYSICS` or `VT_SENSOR` (#!/osrf/gazebo/src/af3ec1827447c026003330cab9922cd50b637651/gazebo/rendering/Scene.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Scene.cc-3189). However for each `Link` a `LinkFrameVisual` is created, which extends `AxisVisual`. The arrow child visuals of this visual are of the type `VT_GUI` and are thus ignored by `Scene::RemoveVisualizations()`.

Practically this means that whenever a model is removed from the world, the visualizations of its Link axes linger, causing things to slow down over time.

Suggested fix:
https://bitbucket.org/ElteHupkes/gazebo/commits/0762db447ea4ac36fa05c42434f4fdc24c0a2972
content.html:
When aVisual is removed in Scene::RemoveVisual(), it calls Scene::RemoveVisualizations() in order to delete eventual additional GUI visualizations of the visual. It only removes these visuals if they are of the type VT_PHYSICS or VT_SENSOR (#!/osrf/gazebo/src/af3ec1827447c026003330cab9922cd50b637651/gazebo/rendering/Scene.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Scene.cc-3189). However for each Link a LinkFrameVisual is created, which extends AxisVisual. The arrow child visuals of this visual are of the type VT_GUI and are thus ignored by Scene::RemoveVisualizations().

Practically this means that whenever a model is removed from the world, the visualizations of its Link axes linger, causing things to slow down over time.

Suggested fix: https://bitbucket.org/ElteHupkes/gazebo/commits/0762db447ea4ac36fa05c42434f4fdc24c0a2972

values.title: Segmentation fault related to physics::Joint::Detach()

content.html:
The segmentation fault is intermittent. When it happens, it always happens after physics::Joint::Detach() is called, but not inside the caller, which is my custom function. The seg fault happens a little after my function has returned. gdb never traces to Detach() or the caller of Detach(); instead, it traces to dQMultiply3() or setBall(), it might trace to other functions too, but I've only traced a few times. This never happens again after removing the Detach() calls.

This is related to this post on Gazebo Answers, which has a more complete gdb backtrace.

The seg fault behavior happens in Gazebo 2.2.6 on Ubuntu 14.04, Gazebo 2.2.6 on OS X Yosemite, Gazebo 5.1.0 on Ubuntu 14.04. These are the versions for ROS Indigo and Jade. Have not tested others.

The physics::Joint being detached is created as a fixed joint from world to a robot by URDF:

  <joint name="world_to_base_link" type="revolute">
    <parent link="world"/>
    <child link="base_link"/>
    <origin xyz="0 0 0"/>
    <limit effort="0" velocity="0" lower="0" upper="0" />
  </joint>

It is found at run-time in a Gazebo WorldPlugin by:

      physics::JointPtr world_to_base_joint_;

      physics::BasePtr wrist_jnt_genericType = world_ -> GetByName (
        "world_to_base_link");
      if (wrist_jnt_genericType)
      {
        world_to_base_joint_ =
          boost::dynamic_pointer_cast <physics::Joint> (wrist_jnt_genericType);
      }
      if (world_to_base_joint_)
      {
        world_to_base_joint_ -> Detach ();
      }

Because there may be some changes from URDF to SDF, I also tried creating the joint programmatically, like how it's done it Gripper.cc. Even then, I still get the same seg fault after Detach().

          physics::JointPtr world_to_base_joint_fresh_;

          world_to_base_joint_fresh_ = physics_ -> CreateJoint ("revolute",
            ground_model);

          world_to_base_joint_fresh_ -> Load (world_link_, base_link_,
            math::Pose ());
          world_to_base_joint_fresh_ -> Init ();
          world_to_base_joint_fresh_ -> SetHighStop (0, 0);
          world_to_base_joint_fresh_ -> SetLowStop (0, 0);

          world_to_base_joint_fresh_ -> Detach ();

values.title: Multiple redundant `JointVisual`s created

content.raw:
`Scene` has multiple entry points for creating `JointVisual`s - apart from actual `Joint` messages received through the transport library it queues such a message for every `Scene` or `Model` message. Every one of these messages results in the creation of a new `JointVisual`, regardless of whether or not this visual already exists. Apart from the obvious redundancy it also leads to a memory leak when the joint is deleted; the visual gets the ID of the joint and only one visual for each ID is stored or deleted.

Assuming that it should still be possible to send redundant joint messages, it would suffice to check if the visual for that joint already exists, see:
https://bitbucket.org/ElteHupkes/gazebo/commits/0c337d6a36159ace6d17065ce6abc708a93bdf72
content.html:
Scene has multiple entry points for creating JointVisuals - apart from actual Joint messages received through the transport library it queues such a message for every Scene or Model message. Every one of these messages results in the creation of a new JointVisual, regardless of whether or not this visual already exists. Apart from the obvious redundancy it also leads to a memory leak when the joint is deleted; the visual gets the ID of the joint and only one visual for each ID is stored or deleted.

Assuming that it should still be possible to send redundant joint messages, it would suffice to check if the visual for that joint already exists, see: https://bitbucket.org/ElteHupkes/gazebo/commits/0c337d6a36159ace6d17065ce6abc708a93bdf72

values.title: Circular references in `Visual` lead to memory leaks

content.raw: `Visual`s hold a shared pointer reference to their parents as well as to their children. This circular reference leads to the memory for these visuals never being released when a visual with children (this would include any joint, link and inertia visuals because they have arrows) is removed from the world. To fix this, `VisualPrivate::parent` should be a weak pointer rather than a shared pointer, as done in https://bitbucket.org/ElteHupkes/gazebo/commits/6179bf6c1b6d94aa8a7e9367b8c371fbbb84ca70.
content.html: Visuals hold a shared pointer reference to their parents as well as to their children. This circular reference leads to the memory for these visuals never being released when a visual with children (this would include any joint, link and inertia visuals because they have arrows) is removed from the world. To fix this, VisualPrivate::parent should be a weak pointer rather than a shared pointer, as done in https://bitbucket.org/ElteHupkes/gazebo/commits/6179bf6c1b6d94aa8a7e9367b8c371fbbb84ca70.

values.title: Delay on IMU orientation measurement

content.raw:
During last summer some users of the Gazebo-based iCub simulator reported some strange behaviors in the simulated IMU orientation measurement.  

In particular they reported some strange delays in the measured orientation. that were partially resolved by this commit:  https://bitbucket.org/traversaro/gazebo-fork/commits/00b21643a0d8fca466aa18b53e954f3ddc37409b?at=imuOrientationWithNoDelay in a forked version of Gazebo. Note that this delay issue is not affecting the large part of Gazebo users, because the ROS IMU plugin is not using the Gazebo IMU sensor.

Porting that fix upstream was on my todo list since then, but I had some problem in understanding the design of the IMU Sensor. In particular it seems that for some reason the linear/angular velocity of the link is read from a topic (with the delay/timing uncertainty that the topic communication implies, especially under heavy load), while the pose is read directly from the methods of the Link class, as the other "simple" sensors such as `force_torque` and `accelerometer` do. There is some reason for this IMU specificity?
content.html:
During last summer some users of the Gazebo-based iCub simulator reported some strange behaviors in the simulated IMU orientation measurement.

In particular they reported some strange delays in the measured orientation. that were partially resolved by this commit: https://bitbucket.org/traversaro/gazebo-fork/commits/00b21643a0d8fca466aa18b53e954f3ddc37409b?at=imuOrientationWithNoDelay in a forked version of Gazebo. Note that this delay issue is not affecting the large part of Gazebo users, because the ROS IMU plugin is not using the Gazebo IMU sensor.

Porting that fix upstream was on my todo list since then, but I had some problem in understanding the design of the IMU Sensor. In particular it seems that for some reason the linear/angular velocity of the link is read from a topic (with the delay/timing uncertainty that the topic communication implies, especially under heavy load), while the pose is read directly from the methods of the Link class, as the other "simple" sensors such as force_torque and accelerometer do. There is some reason for this IMU specificity?

values.title: Move gravity from physics to world

content.raw:
[sdformat pull request 247](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/247/move-gravity-and-magnetic_field-tags-from/diff) moved the gravity element from `PhysicsEngine` to the `World` class. This API needs to be changed in gazebo too.

If this is too much work, then we should revert pull request #247
content.html:
sdformat pull request 247 moved the gravity element from PhysicsEngine to the World class. This API needs to be changed in gazebo too.

If this is too much work, then we should revert pull request #247

values.title: ODE gearbox test times out in debug mode

content.raw:
The test [passes in 115 seconds](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-default-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/42/testReport/(root)/ODEGearboxJoint_TEST/) in release mode, but [consistently fails via timeout in debug mode](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci_BTDebug-default-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/13/testReport/(root)/INTEGRATION_joint_gearbox/test_ran/). The timeout is 240 seconds.

This is not surprising, since the `JointTestRevolute.SimplePendulum/0` test takes [48 seconds in release mode](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-default-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/42/testReport/(root)/PhysicsEngines_JointTestRevolute/SimplePendulum_0/) and [117 seconds in debug mode](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci_BTDebug-default-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/13/testReport/(root)/PhysicsEngines_JointTestRevolute/SimplePendulum_0/).

We should expand the timeout for the gearbox test.
content.html:
The test passes in 115 seconds in release mode, but consistently fails via timeout in debug mode. The timeout is 240 seconds.

This is not surprising, since the JointTestRevolute.SimplePendulum/0 test takes 48 seconds in release mode and 117 seconds in debug mode.

We should expand the timeout for the gearbox test.

values.title: Improve scaling models on the server side

content.raw:
Pull request #2020 added scale to model states. Unlike pose, which is absolute, scale is applied on top of geometries' previous sizes. Therefore, the initial value matters when applying a state that changes scale.

The pull request introduced a workaround which divides all geometries by the parent model scale before saving the initial SDF (9e60bc7). This way, subsequent states are applied on top of the initial condition. This solution is prone to bringing problems in the future. A more elegant solution might involve things like adding `<scale>` elements to `<model>`.

Any solution should make sure scaling works for both visuals and collisions in all these situations:

1. Scale a model -> copy -> paste

1. Scale a model -> edit model

1. Open 2 clients connected to the same server and scaling on one should be seen on the other

1. Scale a model -> save the world -> load the world

1. Scale a model while logging -> playback

1. Scale a model -> undo
content.html:
Pull request #2020 added scale to model states. Unlike pose, which is absolute, scale is applied on top of geometries' previous sizes. Therefore, the initial value matters when applying a state that changes scale.

The pull request introduced a workaround which divides all geometries by the parent model scale before saving the initial SDF (9e60bc7). This way, subsequent states are applied on top of the initial condition. This solution is prone to bringing problems in the future. A more elegant solution might involve things like adding <scale> elements to <model>.

Any solution should make sure scaling works for both visuals and collisions in all these situations:

  1. Scale a model -> copy -> paste

  2. Scale a model -> edit model

  3. Open 2 clients connected to the same server and scaling on one should be seen on the other

  4. Scale a model -> save the world -> load the world

  5. Scale a model while logging -> playback

  6. Scale a model -> undo

values.title: Incorrect size of the object when saved file is opened

content.raw:
There is a problem with saving a model in gazebo 2.2.3 (gazebo with ROS). This problem is similar to [this issue](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/1567/incorrect-visual-geom-size-when-saving-a) which was resolved in higher gazebo version. 

steps to reproduce:

1\. open an empty world:  
```
#!c++

roslaunch turtlebot_gazebo turtlebot_world.launch world_file:=/opt/ros/indigo/share/turtlebot_gazebo/worlds/empty.world
```
2\. insert a box

3\. scale box in x, y, z axes

4\. save world, e.g. box.world

5\. close gazebo

6\. open a box.world

There are two problems:

1. width, length and height are default (1 meter).

2. the box is situated over the floor ![Gazebo_011.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3619868568-Gazebo_011.png)
content.html:

3. scale box in x, y, z axes

4. save world, e.g. box.world

5. close gazebo

6. open a box.world

There are two problems:

  1. width, length and height are default (1 meter).

  2. the box is situated over the floor

I'm can try to contribute the fix if someone can tell me where to start looking? @chapulina?

values.title: Camera::SetHFOV functions are ambiguous when a double is passed

content.html:
I've been testing gazebo_ros_pkgs with our gazebo7 candidate, and there's an issue with the rendering::Camera::SetHFOV functions modified in pull request #1995. Currently the function signatures are:

      /// \brief Set the camera FOV (horizontal)
      /// \param[in] _angle Horizontal field of view
      /// \deprecated See function the accepts an ignition::math parameter
      public: void SetHFOV(math::Angle _angle) GAZEBO_DEPRECATED(7.0);

      /// \brief Set the camera FOV (horizontal)
      /// \param[in] _angle Horizontal field of view
      public: void SetHFOV(const ignition::math::Angle &_angle);

The gazebo_ros_camera_utils.cpp file currently calls SetHFOV with a double input, which confuses the compiler since both ignition::math::Angle and gazebo::math::Angle have constructors from type double. So it fails to compile:

gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_ros_camera_utils.cpp: In member function ‘void gazebo::GazeboRosCameraUtils::SetHFOV(const ConstPtr&)’:
gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_ros_camera_utils.cpp:363:36: error: call of overloaded ‘SetHFOV(const _data_type&)’ is ambiguous
   this->camera_->SetHFOV(hfov->data);
                                    ^
gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_ros_camera_utils.cpp:363:36: note: candidates are:
In file included from gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_ros_camera_utils.cpp:41:0:
gazebo/rendering/Camera.hh:301:20: note: void gazebo::rendering::Camera::SetHFOV(gazebo::math::Angle)
       public: void SetHFOV(math::Angle _angle) GAZEBO_DEPRECATED(7.0);
                    ^
gazebo/rendering/Camera.hh:305:20: note: void gazebo::rendering::Camera::SetHFOV(const ignition::math::Angle&)
       public: void SetHFOV(const ignition::math::Angle &_angle);
                    ^

There are workarounds for this, but it's worth keeping in mind as we continue our quest to use ignition::math.

values.title: VMWare rendering: Z Ordering Appears Random

content.raw:
We have two simulations in Gazebo: A pendulum and an acrobot.  

We have the simulations arranged such that the arms are facing the camera.  However, at runtime it appears random what ordering the links are actually rendered at.  Without making any changes, if the simulation is started many times, each run of the simulation will start with an unpredictable ordering.  

From one run, here you can see a pendulum with an expected ordering:

![img_1000.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/957753752-img_1000.png)

The black link of the pendulum is in front of the brown post.

Randomly, on different runs, we'll see the opposite configuration, where the black link is rendered behind the brown post:

![img_1000.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/73412113-img_1000.png)

With an acrobot, that has more parts in the Z direction, there end up being more unpredictable outcomes.  Here's one example:

![screen_shot_2016-01-19_at_11.20.58_am_720.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/455223053-screen_shot_2016-01-19_at_11.20.58_am_720.png)

The dark blue link is the top link (drawn behind the post). The bottom link is light blue, drawn in front of the post.  This configuration of parts is physically impossible.
content.html:
We have two simulations in Gazebo: A pendulum and an acrobot.

We have the simulations arranged such that the arms are facing the camera. However, at runtime it appears random what ordering the links are actually rendered at. Without making any changes, if the simulation is started many times, each run of the simulation will start with an unpredictable ordering.

From one run, here you can see a pendulum with an expected ordering:

The black link of the pendulum is in front of the brown post.

Randomly, on different runs, we'll see the opposite configuration, where the black link is rendered behind the brown post:

With an acrobot, that has more parts in the Z direction, there end up being more unpredictable outcomes. Here's one example:

The dark blue link is the top link (drawn behind the post). The bottom link is light blue, drawn in front of the post. This configuration of parts is physically impossible.

values.title: DART collision shapes always have zero rotation

content.html:
In the method

void DARTCollision::Init()

the code

    if (!planeShape)
    {
      math::Pose relativePose = this->GetRelativePose();
      this->dataPtr->dtCollisionShape->setOffset(
            DARTTypes::ConvVec3(relativePose.pos));
    }

should be changed to

    if (!planeShape)
    {
      math::Pose relativePose = this->GetRelativePose();
      math::Vector3 pos = this->GetRelativePose().pos;
      math::Quaternion q = this->GetRelativePose().rot;
      Eigen::Isometry3d tf;
      tf.fromPositionOrientationScale(Eigen::Vector3d(pos.x, pos.y, pos.z), Eigen::Quaterniond(q.w, q.x, q.y, q.z), Eigen::Vector3d(1,1,1));
      this->dtCollisionShape->setLocalTransform(tf);
    }

as the orientation of the collision object should also be taken into account.

values.title: Model Editor: Keep changes when closing inspector with close button

content.raw:
Currently, changes only persist if you close the inspector pressing `OK`. Closing through the `X` on the top of the window is equivalent to `Reset`.

After using the inspector a few times, I think it might be more intuitive to keep changes on close. It seems to work like this on other applications too.

IssueForNewDevelopers
content.html:
Currently, changes only persist if you close the inspector pressing OK. Closing through the X on the top of the window is equivalent to Reset.

After using the inspector a few times, I think it might be more intuitive to keep changes on close. It seems to work like this on other applications too.

IssueForNewDevelopers

values.title: Model Editor: Warn user on GUI about GTS library missing when trying to extrude SVG

content.raw:
GTS is currently an optional dependency, so some users might not have it installed. 

If a user without GTS tries to [extrude an SVG](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=extrude_svg&cat=model_editor_top), an error is printed to the terminal, but no indication of it is given in the GUI.

It would be good to alert users through the GUI before they try to extrude an SVG, probably by checking for `HAVE_GTS`.

This issue becomes invalid if we make GTS a required dependency.
content.html:
GTS is currently an optional dependency, so some users might not have it installed.

If a user without GTS tries to extrude an SVG, an error is printed to the terminal, but no indication of it is given in the GUI.

It would be good to alert users through the GUI before they try to extrude an SVG, probably by checking for HAVE_GTS.

This issue becomes invalid if we make GTS a required dependency.

values.title: SetForce on Joint has no effect

content.raw:
Hello, When i use the GetForce() method of a Joint, then try to add a torque by using Joint::SetForce() and then again use GetForce(), I sometimes get the same value back on both calls. The setup is as follows:

I'm using the atlas model of drcsim v5.5 with gazebo4. The simulation is stopped and run stepwise from a worldplugin. GetForce and SetForce are called without doing a step in between. In the first time step, it works for every joint, afterwards it works for some joints and for others not. The joints, which work are changing each timestep in an unforseeable manner.

values.title: New event: BeforePhysicsUpdate

content.raw:
I want to do some advanced usage of ODE in Gazebo, and there is almost a blocker for me.

In ODE, you set contact surface parameter after collision checking, but before physics update (and that completely makes sense and I hope the other engines also do it like this).

There is no way for me to call custom code in between the UpdateCollision() and UpdatePhysics() calls in the World::Update callback. 

I only have a possible workaround - to disable the physics engine, make an update (which will do the collision checking and not the physics update), then call my custom code, and call UpdatePhysics() manually afterwards. This may however break a lot of things connected to the WolrdUpdateEnd event, since it'd be called before the actual physics update.

So I propose creating a new event, called e.g. BeforePhysicsUpdate, that'd be triggered after UpdateCollision and before UpdatePhysics.
content.html:
I want to do some advanced usage of ODE in Gazebo, and there is almost a blocker for me.

In ODE, you set contact surface parameter after collision checking, but before physics update (and that completely makes sense and I hope the other engines also do it like this).

There is no way for me to call custom code in between the UpdateCollision() and UpdatePhysics() calls in the World::Update callback.

I only have a possible workaround - to disable the physics engine, make an update (which will do the collision checking and not the physics update), then call my custom code, and call UpdatePhysics() manually afterwards. This may however break a lot of things connected to the WolrdUpdateEnd event, since it'd be called before the actual physics update.

So I propose creating a new event, called e.g. BeforePhysicsUpdate, that'd be triggered after UpdateCollision and before UpdatePhysics.

values.title: In Link Inspector, don't let hitting Enter create new visual

content.raw:
When on the Visual tab in the Link Inspector, pressing Enter creates another visual by selecting the '+Another Visual button'. This should be disabled as it's easy to accidentally create extra visuals without noticing. 

Pressing Enter to see the changes you made causes another visual to be created. With the visual section expanded, this new visual is not visible in the Inspector.
content.html:
When on the Visual tab in the Link Inspector, pressing Enter creates another visual by selecting the '+Another Visual button'. This should be disabled as it's easy to accidentally create extra visuals without noticing.

Pressing Enter to see the changes you made causes another visual to be created. With the visual section expanded, this new visual is not visible in the Inspector.

values.title: Gazebo misuses collision collide bits as category bits.

content.raw:
My feeling is that Gazebo misuses the category bits.

Compare:

gazebo/physics/ode/ODEPhysics.cc, Collide() method:
```
#!c++
if ((_collision1->GetSurface()->collideBitmask &_collision2->GetSurface()->collideBitmask) == 0)
    return;

```

and

deps/opende/src/collision_space_internal.h 

```
#!c++

// test if the category and collide bitfields match
  if ( ((g1->category_bits & g2->collide_bits) ||
	(g2->category_bits & g1->collide_bits)) == 0) {
    return;
  }
```

It seems that ODEPhysics' Collide() method completely ignores the category bits and incorrectly matches two collide masks against each other. Fortunately, dSpaceCollide() still applies the collision vs. category test, but with the superfluous Collide() constraint, the result is different from what sole ODE would do.

Let's make a thinking experiment. I have a BOX and a CYLINDER. I want boxes to collide with cylinders, but not other boxes, and vice versa.

So I set (reading in binary)
```
BOX:       category 01 collide 10
CYLINDER:  category 10 collide 01
```

In pure ODE, the result would be as desired: each object's category is checked aginst the other object's collide mask.
In Gazebo, the above test is performed, but additionally another `if (10 & 01 == 0) return` is performed, which causes that nothing ever collides.

Please, try to tell if I understand all the stuff correctly and haven't done a mistake somewhere in my deliberation. If someone agrees with my ideas, I might try to write a failing test for this.

Another problem is that we can't probably fix this without breaking BC (refer e.g. to Issue #1581 and the tutorial linked from there).

    return;

and

deps/opende/src/collision_space_internal.h 

// test if the category and collide bitfields match
  if ( ((g1->category_bits & g2->collide_bits) ||
    (g2->category_bits & g1->collide_bits)) == 0) {
    return;
  }

It seems that ODEPhysics' Collide() method completely ignores the category bits and incorrectly matches two collide masks against each other. Fortunately, dSpaceCollide() still applies the collision vs. category test, but with the superfluous Collide() constraint, the result is different from what sole ODE would do.

Let's make a thinking experiment. I have a BOX and a CYLINDER. I want boxes to collide with cylinders, but not other boxes, and vice versa.

So I set (reading in binary)

In pure ODE, the result would be as desired: each object's category is checked aginst the other object's collide mask. In Gazebo, the above test is performed, but additionally another if (10 & 01 == 0) return is performed, which causes that nothing ever collides.

Please, try to tell if I understand all the stuff correctly and haven't done a mistake somewhere in my deliberation. If someone agrees with my ideas, I might try to write a failing test for this.

Another problem is that we can't probably fix this without breaking BC (refer e.g. to Issue #1581 and the tutorial linked from there).

values.title: UNIT_ModelListWidget_TEST failure in jenkins homebrew

content.raw:
The [UNIT_ModelListWidget_TEST](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/GazeboDefault/job/gazebo-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/36/testReport/(root)/ModelListWidget_TEST/) is currently passing on the default branch in homebrew jenkins.

It is proposed in pull request #2116 to change the list of tests subject to the `ENABLE_SCREEN_TESTS`. As a strange side-effect of this pull request, the [test is now failing](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/113/testReport/(root)/ModelListWidget_TEST/LinkProperties/). I note that this is strange because the test was already being run on jenkins homebrew and was passing before. This pull request only changes the order in which this test is run, and now it fails.

values.title: ContactManager c++ API doesn't work unless there is a subscriber to `~/physics/contacts`

content.raw: Some days ago I realized that the gazebo::physics::contactManager misses some contacts. I discovered that a model could have first a conatct being not detected by the class, and then being detected later if the user activates the view->contacts option in the gazebo client. My current code to solve the problem uses a contact topic subscriber and is available on this page: http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/12317/some-contacts-not-detected/?comment=12525#post-id-12525
content.html: Some days ago I realized that the gazebo::physics::contactManager misses some contacts. I discovered that a model could have first a conatct being not detected by the class, and then being detected later if the user activates the view->contacts option in the gazebo client. values.title: Switch back to OS tinyxml2 when Ubuntu starts using version 3 or greater

content.raw:
Switched to use Gazebo's internal copy of tinyxml2 because of a bug that occurs when parsing large log files. See pull request #2146.

We should revert back to using the distributed version when Ubuntu starts to use tinyxml2 version 3 or greater.
content.html:
Switched to use Gazebo's internal copy of tinyxml2 because of a bug that occurs when parsing large log files. See pull request #2146.

We should revert back to using the distributed version when Ubuntu starts to use tinyxml2 version 3 or greater.

values.title: INTEGRATION_model_editor_undo fails on Linux when all test cases are run

content.raw:
The test has been disabled for Linux on Jenkins. Locally, each test case passes if ran individually, but if all cases are ran at once, only the first one passes.

This is true even if you change the order of tests, which suggests the problem is in how we're cleaning up and initializing between tests.

The failing points seem to be related to calls to `QTest::mouseRelease` and `QTest::mouseClick` not going through.
content.html:
The test has been disabled for Linux on Jenkins. Locally, each test case passes if ran individually, but if all cases are ran at once, only the first one passes.

This is true even if you change the order of tests, which suggests the problem is in how we're cleaning up and initializing between tests.

The failing points seem to be related to calls to QTest::mouseRelease and QTest::mouseClick not going through.

values.title: Poor Documentation of rendering::DepthCamera + SDF

content.raw:
It was very tough to find out why the newRGBPointCloud event wasn't firing from a rendering::DepthCamera.  The documentation for the ConnectNewRGBPointCloud method should state that this event will only fire if the <sensor>/<camera>/<depth_camera>/<output> element is set to "points" in the depth camera's SDF file.  The documentation is lacking on SDFormat.org as well... the <depth_camera>/<output> description should say what the options for <output> are and how they will effect the camera's output.

Right now the only way to find all of this information out on your own is to look at gazebo's source code and try to figure out how the event is called.

EDIT:  Based on [this bug](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/1865/rendering-depthcamera-does-not-output), it may be the case that the <depth_camera>/<output> SDF element description was intentionally left blank in the SDFormat.org documentation. Setting the <output> to "points" causes a known issue to arise in the rendering::DepthCamera code, which messes up the RGB colors of the point cloud in the gazebo_ros_depth_camera plugin of gazebo_ros_packages.
content.html:
It was very tough to find out why the newRGBPointCloud event wasn't firing from a rendering::DepthCamera. The documentation for the ConnectNewRGBPointCloud method should state that this event will only fire if the <sensor>/<camera>/<depth_camera>/<output> element is set to "points" in the depth camera's SDF file. The documentation is lacking on SDFormat.org as well... the <depth_camera>/<output> description should say what the options for <output> are and how they will effect the camera's output.

Right now the only way to find all of this information out on your own is to look at gazebo's source code and try to figure out how the event is called.

EDIT: Based on this bug, it may be the case that the <depth_camera>/<output> SDF element description was intentionally left blank in the SDFormat.org documentation. Setting the <output> to "points" causes a known issue to arise in the rendering::DepthCamera code, which messes up the RGB colors of the point cloud in the gazebo_ros_depth_camera plugin of gazebo_ros_packages.

values.title: rendering::DepthCamera does not output colors properly for an RGB PointCloud.

content.raw:
The DepthCamera::PostRender() method of the rendering::DepthCamera class in gazebo/rendering/DepthCamera.cc does not output proper RGB colors for each point.  In the PostRender method, if the <depth_camera>/<output> SDF element is set to "points", it creates a float array containing an RGB point cloud and outputs it through the newRGBPointCloud event.  The format of the float array is X, Y, Z, RGB repeated for all points. (pixels really).  The X, Y, and Z floats for all pixels are fine, but the RGB float for all pixels is incorrect.  The RGB float value always comes out to either:

0x3F800000 if no object is seen by the point (aka X = Y = Z = 0)

0x4AA00000 otherwise, no matter what color the object is that is being seen by that point

I took a look at the gazebo_ros_depth_camera.cc plugin source code written by John Hsu for gazebo_ros_pkgs.  I can tell he had the exact same problem here in trying to use the newRGBPointCloud event, and was forced to instead make a computationally expensive workaround by calculating the RGB point cloud from a depth frame after a newDepthFrame event.  You can even see his attempts at debugging the RGB float problem in his "OnNewRGBPointCloud" method, which was abandoned but never removed from the source code.

The same behavior is made evident [in this post](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/5469/does-gazebo_ros_depth_camera-with-points-output-produce-a-color-point-cloud/).
content.html:
The DepthCamera::PostRender() method of the rendering::DepthCamera class in gazebo/rendering/DepthCamera.cc does not output proper RGB colors for each point. In the PostRender method, if the <depth_camera>/<output> SDF element is set to "points", it creates a float array containing an RGB point cloud and outputs it through the newRGBPointCloud event. The format of the float array is X, Y, Z, RGB repeated for all points. (pixels really). The X, Y, and Z floats for all pixels are fine, but the RGB float for all pixels is incorrect. The RGB float value always comes out to either:

0x3F800000 if no object is seen by the point (aka X = Y = Z = 0)

0x4AA00000 otherwise, no matter what color the object is that is being seen by that point

I took a look at the gazebo_ros_depth_camera.cc plugin source code written by John Hsu for gazebo_ros_pkgs. I can tell he had the exact same problem here in trying to use the newRGBPointCloud event, and was forced to instead make a computationally expensive workaround by calculating the RGB point cloud from a depth frame after a newDepthFrame event. You can even see his attempts at debugging the RGB float problem in his "OnNewRGBPointCloud" method, which was abandoned but never removed from the source code.

The same behavior is made evident in this post.

values.title: Document the need to call PhysicsEngine::InitForThread before using RayShape::GetIntersection.

content.raw:
I've faced a problem that was very difficult to trace, so I think improving documentation could help others.

The problem was the following: in a ROS service callback (running on a callback-queue thread), I was calling `RayShape::GetIntersection` to get some colliding object information. Strangely, with basic shapes it worked, but as soon as I added a trimesh into the scene, Gazebo server segfaulted.

I traced down the issue to be caused by not calling `PhysicsEngine::InitForThread` on the ROS callback queue thread. Then, the `GetIntersection` call found no trimesh-trimesh colliders in the thread-local memory, and segfaulted.

I think this is a rather low-level issue and regular users would be surprised by this behavior. In http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=custom_messages , there is the `InitForThread` call as should be, but it is the only place where `GetIntersection` and `InitForThread` are together. The user has no idea when calling `GetIntersection` that it could fail due to this reason.

So I propose at least leaving a note in `GetIntersection` documentation, that the `InitForThread` call could be required.

There might also be other places where this note would be suitable, but I haven't found them. Can you think of any other places?

I traced down the issue to be caused by not calling PhysicsEngine::InitForThread on the ROS callback queue thread. Then, the GetIntersection call found no trimesh-trimesh colliders in the thread-local memory, and segfaulted.

I think this is a rather low-level issue and regular users would be surprised by this behavior. In http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=custom_messages , there is the InitForThread call as should be, but it is the only place where GetIntersection and InitForThread are together. The user has no idea when calling GetIntersection that it could fail due to this reason.

values.title: Highlight surfaces when they touch

content.raw: In the Model Editor, it's difficult to manually position a link along another link so that the surfaces are touching, because it's difficult to tell if they're touching. If we did collision checking, we could briefly highlight surfaces when they come in contact with another surface. This would provide valuable feedback, and is a standard interaction in many design tools.

values.title: LogPlay_TEST/NoEndTag fails on 32-bit trusty

content.html:
The LogPlay_TEST/NoEndTag test is failing on 32-bit trusty.

I've reproduced the error on a 32bit/ubuntu:14.04 docker image on my desktop. It seems that LogPlay is successfully inserting the missing </gazebo_log> tag, but it is not detecting it properly with the following calls in LogPlay_TEST:

  // Open the temporary file, which should now have the proper end tag
  std::ifstream inFile(tmpFilename);

  std::string endTag = "</gazebo_log>";

  // Back up the length of the closing tag.
  inFile.seekg(-1 - endTag.length(), std::ios::end);

  // Get the last line
  std::string lastLine;
  std::getline(inFile, lastLine);
...
  // Check that the log file now has the closing end tag
  EXPECT_EQ(lastLine, endTag);

I've verified that the file contains </gazebo_log>, but the expectation still fails.

Also, these same statements are in LogPlay::Open, which causes a different test to append </gazebo_log> to test/logs/invalidHeader.log, so that it winds up with two tags.

Something about those statements isn't working on 32-bit Ubuntu.

values.title: kinematic tag doesn't get loaded from SDF

content.raw:
The kinematic tag for links doesn't get loaded from SDFs (this can be seen by selecting the link in the GUI.) However, Gazebo does respect the "kinematic" property when it is selected manually in the GUI. I'm using Gazebo 5.1.0. 

To reproduce:

* Add the two attached files to a folder in your `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH`
* Open Gazebo, insert the block model.
* click on "block" -> "link"
* Notice `kinematic` is unchecked.

It was reported [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/1034/simbody-init-does-not-read-gravity-mode) and marked as resolved but it's still busted.

values.title: Simbody, Bullet dependencies not added to gazebo-config.cmake

content.raw:
The gazebo-config.cmake doesn't include dependencies on Simbody and Bullet when Gazebo was compiled with Simbody and Bullet support.
This breaks building of ROS packages which fail to link with Gazebo.

I have a patch for this but I'm trying to create a pull request.

```
#!patch

diff -r 61136bf84197 CMakeLists.txt
--- a/CMakeLists.txt	Fri Feb 19 14:59:30 2016 -0800
+++ b/CMakeLists.txt	Fri Mar 11 10:26:53 2016 +0200
@@ -394,6 +394,14 @@
 
   set(PKG_DEPENDS Boost Protobuf SDFormat OGRE)
 
+  if (HAVE_SIMBODY)
+    list(APPEND PKG_DEPENDS "Simbody")
+  endif()
+
+  if (HAVE_BULLET)
+    list(APPEND PKG_DEPENDS "Bullet")
+  endif()
+
   set(cmake_conf_file "cmake/gazebo-config.cmake")
   set(cmake_conf_version_file "cmake/gazebo-config-version.cmake")
   configure_file("${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/${cmake_conf_file}.in" "${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR}/${cmake_conf_file}" @ONLY)
diff -r 61136bf84197 cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake
--- a/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake	Fri Feb 19 14:59:30 2016 -0800
+++ b/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake	Fri Mar 11 10:26:53 2016 +0200
@@ -138,8 +138,10 @@
   #list(APPEND CMAKE_MODULE_PATH ${SimTK_INSTALL_PREFIX}/share/cmake)
   find_package(Simbody)
   if (Simbody_FOUND)
+    message (STATUS "Looking for Simbody - found")
     set (HAVE_SIMBODY TRUE)
   else()
+    message (STATUS "Looking for Simbody - not found")
     BUILD_WARNING ("Simbody not found, for simbody physics engine option, please install libsimbody-dev.")
     set (HAVE_SIMBODY FALSE)
   endif()
diff -r 61136bf84197 cmake/gazebo-config.cmake.in
--- a/cmake/gazebo-config.cmake.in	Fri Feb 19 14:59:30 2016 -0800
+++ b/cmake/gazebo-config.cmake.in	Fri Mar 11 10:26:53 2016 +0200
@@ -114,17 +114,22 @@
       find_package(${dep} REQUIRED)
     endif()
   endif()
-  list(APPEND @PKG_NAME@_INCLUDE_DIRS ${${dep}_INCLUDE_DIRS})
 
   # Protobuf needs to be capitalized to match PROTOBUF_LIBRARIES
   if (${dep} STREQUAL "Protobuf")
-    string (TOUPPER ${dep} dep_lib)
-  else()
-    set (dep_lib ${dep})
+    list(APPEND @PKG_NAME@_INCLUDE_DIRS ${PROTOBUF_INCLUDE_DIRS})
+    list(APPEND @PKG_NAME@_LIBRARIES ${PROTOBUF_LIBRARIES})
+  elseif (${dep} STREQUAL "Bullet")
+    list(APPEND @PKG_NAME@_INCLUDE_DIRS ${BULLET_INCLUDE_DIRS})
+    list(APPEND @PKG_NAME@_LIBRARIES ${BULLET_LIBRARIES})
+  elseif (${dep} STREQUAL "Simbody")
+    list(APPEND @PKG_NAME@_INCLUDE_DIRS ${Simbody_INCLUDE_DIR})
+    list(APPEND @PKG_NAME@_LIBRARIES ${Simbody_LIBRARIES})
+  else ()
+    list(APPEND @PKG_NAME@_INCLUDE_DIRS ${${dep}_INCLUDE_DIRS})
+    list(APPEND @PKG_NAME@_LIBRARIES ${${dep}_LIBRARIES})
   endif()
 
-  list(APPEND @PKG_NAME@_LIBRARIES ${${dep_lib}_LIBRARIES})
-
   # When including OGRE, also include the Terrain and Paging components
   if (${dep} STREQUAL "OGRE")
     list(APPEND GAZEBO_INCLUDE_DIRS ${OGRE_Terrain_INCLUDE_DIRS}

```

values.title: Topic name or index in Subscriber callback

content.raw:
Based on this question: http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/12840/topic-name-or-index-in-subscriber-callback/

The idea is to allow the subscribers to bind more parameters other that just the message (indices, ID, names, etc). In ROS this is possible but the current `Node::Subscribe()` signatures do not allow for this.
content.html:
Based on this question: http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/12840/topic-name-or-index-in-subscriber-callback/

The idea is to allow the subscribers to bind more parameters other that just the message (indices, ID, names, etc). In ROS this is possible but the current Node::Subscribe() signatures do not allow for this.

values.title: Modifying physics properties in gzclient causes assertion

content.raw:
Since pull request #2120 and pull request #2155, modifying physics properties via gzclient causes an assertion (branches gazebo7 and default):

~~~
Assertion failed: (::gazebo::msgs::Physics_Type_IsValid(value)),
function set_type, file gazebo/msgs/physics.pb.h, line 371.
~~~

I've added a testcase to `UNIT_ModelListWidget_TEST` in [branch model_list_test](#!/osrf/gazebo/compare/model_list_test%0Dgazebo7) that [reproduces this failure](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/191/testReport/junit/UNIT_ModelListWidget_TEST/xml/_empty_/).

I have a fix and will submit a pull request shortly.
content.html:
Since pull request #2120 and pull request #2155, modifying physics properties via gzclient causes an assertion (branches gazebo7 and default):

Assertion failed: (::gazebo::msgs::Physics_Type_IsValid(value)),
function set_type, file gazebo/msgs/physics.pb.h, line 371.

I've added a testcase to UNIT_ModelListWidget_TEST in branch model_list_test that reproduces this failure.
